sec.title: Purpose:
sec.p: the Thai PPS Adult Suandok tool was translated from the Palliative Performance Scale (PPSv2) and had been used in Chiang Mai, Thailand for several years.

sec.title: Aim:
sec.p: to test the reliability and validity of the Thai translation of PPSv2.

sec.title: Design:
sec.p: a set of 22 palliative cases were used to determine a PPS score on Time-1, and repeated two weeks later as Time-2. A survey questionnaire was also completed for qualitative analysis.

sec.title: Participants:
sec.p: a total of 70 nurses and physicians from Maharaj Nakorn Hospital in Chiang Mai participated.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: The Time-1 intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC) for absolute agreement is 0.911 (95% CI 0.86–0.96) and for consistency is 0.92 (95% CI 0.87–0.96). The Time-2 ICC for agreement is 0.905 (95% CI 0.85–0.95) and for consistency is 0.912 (95% CI 0.86–0.96). These findings indicate good agreement among participants and also were somewhat higher in the Time-2 re-test phase. Cohen’s kappa score is 0.55, demonstrating a moderate agreement. Thematic analysis from the surveys showed that 91% felt PPS to be a valuable clinical tool overall, with it being ‘very useful’ or ‘useful’ in several areas, including care planning (78% and 20%), disease monitoring (69% and 27%) and prognostication (61% and 31%), respectively. Some respondents noted difficulty in determining appropriate scores in paraplegic patients or those with feeding tubes, while others found the instructions long or difficult.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: the Thai PPS Adult Suandok translated tool has good inter- and intra-rater reliability and can be used regularly for clinical care.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The Palliative Performance Scale (PPS) was first introduced by Anderson and Downing in 1996 as a new tool to measure the performance status of palliative care patients1 and has been used for communication, analysis of home nursing care workload, profiling admissions and discharges to the hospice unit and prognostication. The PPS has been translated into other languages, including French, Japanese, German, Portuguese, Spanish, Dutch and Thai. The Thai version is known as the Thai PPS Adult Suandok, where the word Suandok is representative of the University Hospital in Chiang Mai, Thailand and means ‘field of flowers’.2

Several articles on the reliability and validity of the PPS have been published.3–10 A formal study by Ho et al.11 showed high intraclass correlation (0.96) and consistency (Cohen’s kappa 0.67). Other documented areas where the PPS is used include monitoring the impact of disease progression and care planning. In the Canadian Health Services Research Foundation report.12 on Collaborative Care Plans, the PPS was one of the assessment tools recommended. In another article on advance planning and palliative care in nursing homes in the USA, Levy13 also used the PPS for prognostication and palliative care interventions. The BC Pharmacare Program of British Columbia, Canada, contains a guideline for their Palliative Drug Benefit Program, stating that eligible patients have to be in the terminal stage of illness with a six-month prognosis, and the entry point is usually PPS 50% or lower.14

Although Ho et al.11 demonstrated PPSv2 as reliable and valid, it is unclear if the Thai PPS Adult Suandok translation has similar values in the Thai culture for palliative care patients. PPSv2 is a new tool in several medical and nursing schools in Thailand. The Maharaj Nakorn Chiang Mai (MNCM) hospital is the first hospital to use the Thai PPSv2 Adult Suandok translation for assessing the performance status of palliative care patients. They identify three groups of palliative care patients in the MNCM hospital: patients with incurable and serious illness who are terminal; cancer patients at all stages; and non-cancer end-of-life patients. Currently, MNCM hospital is the first known hospital globally to use the PPS regularly for these three groups of patients in their 1400-bed hospital.15 PPSv2 has already been found useful as one component of the Suandok Palliative Care Model, which includes a palliative care Collaborative Care Plan-Lite (CCP) modified from that of Queen’s University in Canada and Cancer Care Ontario.12,16 This CCP divides palliative care patients into three categories using PPS levels: PPS 100%–70% as stable, PPS 60%–40% as transitional and PPS 30%–0% as end of life.

The Thai PPS Adult Suandok now requires reliability testing and the specific objectives are to examine the inter- and intra-rater reliability of the Thai PPS tool by clinicians using a set of simulated palliative care patient case scenarios and to examine the validity of the Thai PPS by content validation and surveying clinicians on its purpose and usefulness.

sec.title: Research design
sec.p: The study used a case format similar to Ho et al.,11 translated to Thai language. A set of 22 simulated palliative care patients’ cases were based on real patient scenarios but modified for anonymity and contained brief descriptions of each case’s demographics, primary diagnosis, medical, social and family history, signs and symptoms, medications and care plan. The cases from the Ho et al. study were reviewed and reaffirmed by the authors. An early version of the Thai translation of PPSv2 was completed a year prior to the study by the palliative nursing team. A back translation was completed and corroborated by an academic expert at Chiang Mai University, which was then reviewed and accepted by palliative experts in Victoria. Two interpretive changes were made to create the official Thai PPS Adult Suandok, which did not alter the meaning of the Thai table: ‘total care’ was translated as ‘total assistance’ and ‘mouth care only’ as ‘nothing per oral.’ A few changes in the instructions and case examples were minor and not substantive. PPSv2 is shown in the Appendix to demonstrate where these interpretive changes were noted in context.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: Participants were recruited via purposive and convenience sampling consisting of staff nurses in palliative care units, general medical and surgical, gynecology, radiation therapy and orthopedic departments, and also oncology nurses and physicians who work in MNCM hospital and care for palliative care patients. They may or may not have been currently using the Thai PPS. Sample size calculations were based on the Ho et al.11 study with a minimum required of 44 raters. Letters of Invitation were sent out to staff until a maximum of 70 participants were enrolled.

In Part A participants reviewed and scored the 22 cases (Time-1 data). Two weeks later, all participants were sent a second package to complete a re-test of the same cases but re-ordered at random (Time-2 data). The data was entered into an Excel spreadsheet and anonymized before analysis. In Part B participants were surveyed to elicit feedback on their perceived usefulness and to determine the validity of the PPS. A thematic analysis process was used in initially transcribing the results and after repeated readings of the data, meaning units were identified, reviewed and grouped by the word and meaning patterns into themes.

sec.title: Data analysis
sec.p: Data was analyzed for inter- and intra-rater reliability using the single rating intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC) for absolute agreement and for consistency using two-way random-effects models. The ICCs were obtained for each time period. Single rating measures were used because interest in this study is on ICC measures for individual raters rather than averages of independent measures.

Participant reliability was evaluated using Cohen’s kappa, which is a chance-corrected measure of agreement between two participants. Strictly speaking, the derivation of the standard error for kappa depends on the raters acting independently of one another.17 Therefore, the standard errors are subject to error since here the same rater is used at the two time periods. Rater reliability was also evaluated using a randomized block analysis of variance (ANOVA) incorporating the rater as a random effect. This analysis accommodates the dependent nature of the data, where the same rater is providing observations for both time points. It allows evaluation of the effects over time and possible interactions of time with the cases.

Individual case results are also shown by cross-tab table, box plots and comparison for each case with the previous expert group’s indication of PPS scores. The data for the reliability portion of the study was analyzed using SPSS 15.0 and R version 2.11.0 software. Part B of the validation section was performed through content validation of surveys with palliative staff at MNCM hospital, discussing their experiences using the PPS. The study was reviewed by and received ethics approvals from both the Chiang Mai University Faculty of Medicine and the University of Victoria Research Ethics Boards.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: There were 70 participant raters consisting of 51 nurses and 19 physicians who completed both time periods. From table 1 the Time-1 ICC for absolute agreement is 0.911 (95% CI 0.86–0.96) and for consistency is 0.92 (95% CI 0.87–0.96). The Time-2 ICC for agreement is 0.905 (95% CI 0.85–0.95) and for consistency is 0.912 (95% CI 0.86–0.96). These findings indicate good agreement among participants and the scores are somewhat higher in the Time-2 re-test phase. Cohen’s kappa score is 0.55, which demonstrates a moderate agreement according to Landis and Koch.18

sec.p: Figures 1 and 2 show box-plot distributions of the PPS percentage ratings. In 19 of 22 cases for Time-1 there was high agreement where the median of the raters was the same as the prior expert group determination of PPS scores. The three exceptions to this were cases #2, 8 and 13; in Time-2, data agreement improved to 20 of 22 cases with only cases # 8 and 13 remaining one level different.

sec.p: Table 2 shows the results of the qualitative open-ended questionnaire on the clinical utility of the PPS. Over one-half of the 70 surveyed had been using the PPS for six months or more and 99% indicated it as a valuable tool in patient assessment at end of life. Categories where the PPS was found ‘very useful’ include care planning 78%, transition and disease monitoring 69%, prognostication 61% and discharge planning 11%, and 11% found that it is very useful in giving information to the family members of the patients. Moreover, 44.4% of subjects found it very useful in needs assessment for the nursing care of the patients. A total of 22.2% of subjects found that it is very useful in communication among the collaborative care plan. A total of 11% of subjects found that it is very useful in doing research.

sec.p: Example quotes from thematic analysis show the PPS as useful for decision making and care planning where one physician stated that when the PPS level was below 30%, he would ‘advise the patients and family members about palliative care.’ Three respondents said they ‘use the PPS level as the cut point for the treatments of the patients: surgery or no surgery; curative treatment or palliative care.’ Another noted that ‘when the PPS level is lower quickly, it means that the patients have lower self-care. We will provide more nursing care and health education to the patients and family members.’ Several nurses stated that the PPS level ‘helps us to provide palliative care as a guideline of multidisciplinary collaborative care plan’ where they categorize three groups of PPS scores, 0%–30%, PPS 40%–60% and PPS 70%–100%, to guide information and care plans.

Regarding nursing care, one person stated that ‘the PPS level can be used in the plan for nursing and nursing productivity, prognosis and the symptoms of the patients when we transfer the patient to another ward’ and another nurse said, ‘when the patients have a PPS score in the lower level, the nurses will recognize that these patients need more nursing care than usual.’

Some problems were also noted by 39% of those using the PPS. Although several people felt the instructions and definitions were too long or unclear (four people), others wanted more details to help determine the PPS level in patients with jejunostomy tubes or who are paraplegic. One nurse felt that it was hard to assess in cerebrovascular disease patients and requested ‘more explanation about movement and eating for using in these patients.’ Another thought it difficult to decide the PPS level in patients who have unstable symptoms. Four people found it hard to make decisions about ‘which PPS level is the best fit, what to do with PPS % level scores that fall in between two levels’ and requested finer gradations of PPS percentage. In addition, four nurses found occasional differences between the first and the second nurse when assessing the PPS level in the same patient.

Finally, although acknowledging its value as a communication tool, one nurse noted that ‘many physicians and medical students did not know about PPSv2 and thought there should be more teaching about PPSv2 to have much benefit in clinical care.’

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The results of the inter- and intra-rater reliability testing indicate that the Thai PPS Adult Suandok is a reliable tool and consistent with the original expert group’s determination of correct PPS scores in the Ho et al.11 study. This is of particular note in that this study included more participants and each participant completed all 22 cases as compared to one-half of that in the other. The kappa score of 0.55 is somewhat lower than that in the Ho et al. study of 0.67 and 0.71, and although 0.55 is acceptable as moderate agreement,18 a future detailed study of psychometric properties of the Thai version would help to clarify. Although 39% of survey participants noted some difficulty in using the PPS, it is unclear whether translation accuracy, cultural influences or varying familiarity with the use of the PPS may account for this. However, with only two interpretation issues during the back translation, both palliative groups felt the Thai translation was accurate. In addition, there were only minor word alterations in the 22 cases and the Thai palliative team was confident with the types of cases and issues within the study, thereby reducing the likelihood of cultural misinterpretation. Although 33% of participants were new or had used the PPS for less than six months, 99% felt it was clinically useful and 81% agreed the instructions were adequate and useful.

Qualitatively, there is face validity that Thai clinicians find the PPS a useful tool for care planning, transition and disease monitoring, prognostication, discharge planning and for information for patients and families. The difficulties in using the PPS in patients with neurological deficits or intake diversion (e.g. J-tubes) are not unique to the Thai culture. The Ho et al.11 study found similar challenges and, as a result, a Q&A document is available with details and cases that were sent by clinicians to Victoria over several years, and many have found these clarifications helpful in teaching and to enhance accurate usage.19

Of additional note is that in the MNCM hospital, the PPS is currently being used for patients on many wards on a weekly or a daily basis. This is unique and the authors are unaware of such use anywhere else globally. Although there has been anecdotal criticism on various wards in using a ‘palliative’ tool for all patients, it can be implemented when viewed as a functional assessment tool only and consideration could be given to using the term ‘patient performance scale’ to reduce concerns. In those situations, patient PPS scores may well improve post-operatively or following stroke or vehicle accidents. This area of use is new and unexplored.

A significant limitation of this study is that the cases are paper based. Even though they were drawn from real patient situations, it is unclear whether similar reliability would occur if clinicians had actually examined the patients. This would have been impractical and unethical to have 70 people do this, especially on two separate occasions, but does limit the interpretation of the results.

In summary, these results affirm that clinicians can use the Thai PPS Adult Suandok tool with reasonable confidence in its reliability when assessing the functional status of palliative care patients. Although fairly simple to learn and use, some staff at the MNCM hospital felt more details and instructions are needed, but then found it useful for daily or weekly practice. PPSv2 helps to monitor the progress of functional ability and disease trajectory. PPSv2 is very useful in communication about palliative care patients among nurses and physicians. It has been incorporated into a collaborative care plan guideline based on three groups of PPS levels. Future studies should assess its clinical value, both in hospital and community settings, for communication, functional assessment and prognostication within the Thai culture.

Thus, ‘leftward’ columns take precedence over ‘rightward’ columns. Also, see ‘definitions of terms’ below. © Victoria Hospice Society.

sec.title: Definition of Terms for PPS
sec.p: As noted below, some of the terms have similar meanings with the differences being more readily apparent as one reads horizontally across each row to find an overall ‘best fit’ using all five columns.

list-item.p:
Ambulation (Use item Self-Care to help decide the level)
Full – no restrictions or assistance
Reduced ambulation – degree to which the patient can walk and transfer with occasional assistance
Mainly sit/lie vs. Mainly in bed – the amount of time that the patient is able to sit up or needs to lie down
Totally bed bound – unable to get out of bed or do self-care

Activity & Evidence of Disease (Use Ambulation to help decide the level.)
Activity – Refers to normal activities linked to daily routines (ADL), house work and hobbies/leisure.
Job/work – Refers to normal activities linked to both paid and unpaid work, including homemaking and volunteer activities.
Both include cases in which a patient continues the activity but may reduce either the time or effort involved.
Evidence of Disease
No evidence of disease – Individual is normal and healthy with no physical or investigative evidence of disease.
‘Some,’ ‘significant,’ and ‘extensive’ disease – Refers to physical or investigative evidence which shows disease progression, sometimes despite active treatments.
Example 1: Breast cancer:
some = a local recurrence
significant = one or two metastases in the lung or bone
extensive = multiple metastases (lung, bone, liver or brain), hypercalcemia or other complication
Example 2: CHF:
some = regular use of diuretic &/or ACE inhibitors to control
significant = exacerbations of CHF, effusion or edema necessitating increases or changes in drug management
extensive = 1 or more hospital admissions in past 12 months for acute CHF & general decline with effusions, edema, SOB
Full – Able to do all normal activities such as transfer out of bed, walk, wash, toilet and eat without assistance.
Occasional assistance – Requires minor assistance from several times a week to once every day, for the activities noted above.
Considerable assistance – Requires moderate assistance every day, for some of the activities noted above (getting to the bathroom, cutting up food, etc.)

Mainly assistance – Requires major assistance every day, for most of the activities noted above (getting up, washing face and shaving, etc.). Can usually eat with minimal or no help. This may fluctuate with level of fatigue.
Total care – Always requires assistance for all care. May or may not be able to chew and swallow food.
Normal – eats normal amounts of food for the individual as when healthy
Normal or reduced – highly variable for the individual; ‘reduced’ means intake is less than normal amounts when healthy
Minimal to sips – very small amounts, usually pureed or liquid, and well below normal intake.
Mouth care only – no oral intake
Full – fully alert and orientated, with normal (for the patient) cognitive abilities (thinking, memory, etc. )
Full or confusion – level of consciousness is full or may be reduced. If reduced, confusion denotes delirium or dementia which may be mild, moderate or severe, with multiple possible etiologies.
Full or drowsy +/– confusion – level of consciousness is full or may be markedly reduced; sometimes included in the term stupor. Implies fatigue, drug side effects, delirium or closeness to death.

Drowsy or coma +/– confusion – no response to verbal or physical stimuli; some reflexes may or may not remain. The depth of coma may fluctuate throughout a 24 hour period. Usually indicates imminent death
